text: sadness
quote: dolefulness

text: gloominess
quote: dismalness

text: a person who has suffered
quote: bereaved

text: describing how she can't explain it
quote:
It is not my tongue, or pen, can express the sorrows of my heart, and
bitterness of my spirit that I had at this departure

text: shows her faith
quote:
God was with
me in a wonderful manner

the Lord renewed my
strength still, and carried me along

text: unfortunate
quote: lamentable

it was easy for me to see how
righteous it was with God to cut off the thread of my life and cast me
out of His presence forever

text: describing the death of her child
quote:
I must and could lie down by my dead babe, side by side all
the night after

text: her children
quote:
I had one child
dead, another in the wilderness, I knew not where, the third they
would not let me come near to:

text: describes her negative feelings turning positive after reading the Bible
quote:
that there was no mercy for me, that the blessings
were gone, and the curses come in their room, and that I had lost my
opportunity

no Christian soul near me,
and yet how hath the Lord preserved me in safety?

text: Why was the cattle comforting?
quote:
I saw a place where
English cattle had been. That was comfort to me, such as it was

text: they were taking her food away from her
quote:
they got half of it
away from me

text: first time she cries before them
quote:
the first time to my remembrance, that
I wept before them

text: she begins knitting for things
quote: he asked me to make a cap for his boy

text: granted permission to go see her son
quote:
I asked liberty to go and
see him; they bade me go, and away I went; but quickly lost myself,
traveling over hills and through swamps, and could not find the way to
him

no Christian friend was
near him, to do any office of love for him, either for soul or body

text: does this mean she is waiting to die? "heavenly rest"
quote:
I hope all these
wearisome steps that I have taken, are but a forewarning to me of the
heavenly rest

Which stilled my spirit for the
present

On the tenth of February 1675, came the Indians with great numbers upon
Lancaster
text: February 1675, Lancaster. King Philip's war is from June 1675-April 1678.
House on fire.
quote:
About two hours (according to my observation, in that
amazing time) they had been about the house before they prevailed to
fire it (which they did with flax and hemp, which they brought out of
the barn, and there being no defense about the house, only two flankers
at two opposite corners and one of them not finished); they fired it
once and one ventured out and quenched it, but they quickly fired it
again, and that took.

text: Indians shoot at her and her kids as they try to leave.
quote:
Then I took my children (and one of
my sisters', hers) to go forth and leave the house: but as soon as
we came to the door and appeared, the Indians shot so thick that the
bullets rattled against the house, as if one had taken an handful of
stones and threw them, so that we were fain to give back.

text: Brother-in-law dead.
quote:
No sooner were we out of the house, but my
brother-in-law (being before wounded, in defending the house, in or near
the throat) fell down dead

text: She and her kid in arm are shot.
quote:
ne went through my side, and the same (as would
seem) through the bowels and hand of my dear child in my arms

text: Nephew beaten. (dead or unconscious? unclear)
quote:
One of my
elder sisters' children, named William, had then his leg broken, which
the Indians perceiving, they knocked him on [his] head.

text: Sister shot and died.
quote:
she
said, "And Lord, let me die with them," which was no sooner said, but
she was struck with a bullet, and fell down dead over the threshold.

text: Indians separate her from her children.
quote:
the Indians laid hold of us, pulling me one
way, and the children another, and said, "Come go along with us"; I told
them they would kill me: they answered, if I were willing to go along
with them, they would not hurt me.

Of
thirty-seven persons who were in this one house, none escaped either
present death, or a bitter captivity, save only one, who might say as
he, "And I only am escaped alone to tell the News" (Job 1.15). There
were twelve killed, some shot, some stabbed with their spears, some
knocked down with their hatchets.
text: 12 out of 37 people killed. 1 escapes to tell the news. (Big house!)
24 captives
quote:
for there
were twenty-four of us taken alive and carried captive.

text: They also took livestock from the town?
quote:
And as miserable was the waste that was there made
of horses, cattle, sheep, swine, calves, lambs, roasting pigs, and fowl
(which they had plundered in the town), some roasting, some lying and
burning, and some boiling to feed our merciless enemies; who were joyful
enough, though we were disconsolate.

text: What happened to her kids? Confused. And her husband's away at sea.
quote:
All was gone, my husband
gone (at least separated from me, he being in the Bay; and to add to my
grief, the Indians told me they would kill him as he came homeward), my
children gone, my relations and friends gone, our house and home and all
our comforts—within door and without—all was gone (except my life),
and I knew not but the next moment that might go too.

text: But she has a dying baby.
quote:
There remained
nothing to me but one poor wounded babe, and it seemed at present
worse than death that it was in such a pitiful condition, bespeaking
compassion, and I had no refreshing for it, nor suitable things to
revive it.
THE FIRST REMOVE
text: An abandoned house on a hill still in sight of Lancaster.

quote:
About a
mile we went that night, up upon a hill within sight of the town

text: Her kid is an "it?" And old enough to talk.
quote:
One of the Indians carried my poor wounded
babe upon a horse; it went moaning all along, "I shall die, I shall
die." I went on foot after it, with sorrow that cannot be expressed.

At length I took it off the horse, and carried it in my arms till my
strength failed, and I fell down with it.
text: Was she or wasn't she shot?

quote:
After this it quickly began to snow, and when night came on, they
stopped, and now down I must sit in the snow, by a little fire, and a
few boughs behind me, with my sick child in my lap; and calling much for
water, being now (through the wound) fallen into a violent fever.
text: Stopped at a campfire in the snow.
Snowy campfire.
quote: THE SECOND REMOVE

text: She was shot.
quote:
My own
wound also growing so stiff that I could scarce sit down or rise up;

text: It's her daughter.
quote:
A very wearisome and tedious day I had of it; what
with my own wound, and my child's being so exceeding sick, and in a
lamentable condition with her wound.

text: 3 days w/o food.
quote:
Wednesday night
to Saturday night

text: Wenimesset
quote: Wenimesset, northward of Quabaug
THE THIRD REMOVE
text: Wenimesset
What do the Indians want with English captives for so long?
quote:
This day there came to me one Robert Pepper (a man belonging
to Roxbury) who was taken in Captain Beers's fight, and had been now a
considerable time with the Indians

text: And they let their captives travel?
quote:
Hearing, I say, that I was in this Indian town, he
obtained leave to come and see me.

text: Threats to kill her wounded daughter.
quote:
one Indian would come and tell me one hour that "your master
will knock your child in the head," and then a second, and then a third,
"your master will quickly knock your child in the head."

text: Her daughter dies.
quote:
About two hours in the night, my sweet babe like a lamb departed
this life on Feb. 18, 1675.

Quinnapin, who was a Sagamore, and
married King Philip's wife's sister
text: Quinnapin, married King Philip's wife's sister?
But she has another living daughter, Mary (10).
quote:
I went to see my daughter Mary, who
was at this same Indian town, at a wigwam not very far off

text: Her son was also captured, but alive.
quote:
I knew not where he was, till I was
informed by himself, that he was amongst a smaller parcel of Indians,
whose place was about six miles off

text: An Indian brings her a Bible from Medfield.
quote:
One of the Indians that
came from Medfield fight, had brought some plunder, came to me, and
asked me, if I would have a Bible, he had got one in his basket.

text: Indians have 8 children, 2 women captives.
quote:
There were now besides myself nine English captives
in this place (all of them children, except one woman).
thirty miles from any English town
text: 30 miles away from English towns
last time she sees Mary
quote:
Here I parted from
my daughter Mary

text: Pregnant woman wants to go home; Indians strip her, beat her and her child, and dance around her.
quote:
gathered
a great company together about her and stripped her naked, and set her
in the midst of them, and when they had sung and danced about her (in
their hellish manner) as long as they pleased they knocked her on head,
and the child in her arms with her

we traveled about half a day
or little more, and came to a desolate place in the wilderness, where
there were no wigwams or inhabitants before; we came about the middle
of the afternoon to this place
text: half day's travel. stop in the middle of nowhere
stayed for 4 days
quote:
At this place we continued about
four days.
THE FOURTH REMOVE
text: middle of nowhere

quote: Medfield

text: Indians are running from the English.
quote:
For they went as if they had
gone for their lives, for some considerable way, and then they made a
stop, and chose some of their stoutest men, and sent them back to hold
the English army in play whilst the rest escaped.

text: Banquaug river
quote: Banquaug river

text: Took 2 days to cross the river.
quote:
A certain number of us got over
the river that night, but it was the night after the Sabbath before all
the company was got over.

text: Banquaug river
quote: THE FIFTH REMOVE

text: English army gives up the chase at the river.
quote:
On that very day came the English army after them to
this river, and saw the smoke of their wigwams, and yet this river put a
stop to them. God did not give them courage or activity to go over after
us.

text: Stopped near a swamp
quote:
We came that day to a great
swamp, by the side of which we took up our lodging that night.

text: swamp
quote: THE SIXTH REMOVE

text: Squakeag
quote: Squakeag

text: Come across an abandoned English place.
quote:
As we went along, I saw a place where
English cattle had been. That was comfort to me, such as it was.

text: Did the Indians drive out the English?
quote: deserted English fields,

text: Squakeag
quote: THE SEVENTH REMOVE

On the morrow morning we must go over the river, i.e. Connecticut, to
meet with King Philip.
text: Connecticut river?
English scouts are spotted.
quote:
The cause of this rout was, as I thought, their espying some English
scouts, who were thereabout.

text: She meets her son again.
quote:
As I sat amongst them, musing of things past, my son Joseph unexpectedly
came to me.

But to
return, we traveled on till night; and in the morning, we must go over
the river to Philip's crew.
text: Traveled through the night and crossed the river.
Babylon and Zion
quote:
But now I may say as Psalm 137.1, "By the Rivers of Babylon,
there we sate down: yea, we wept when we remembered Zion."
Then I went to see King Philip.
text: Ah, King Philip is an Indian. Aka Metacomet (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metacomet). This is taking place shortly before King Philip's war.
Marlborough. Confused by rest of this passage. I assume "Praying" means Christian.
quote: Marlborough's Praying Indians, which Capt. Mosely brought to Boston
King Philip

text: Northampton
quote: Northampton

text: King Philip gives her English money for a knitted shirt.
quote:
Philip spake to me to make a shirt for
his boy, which I did, for which he gave me a shilling.

text: Indian master lets her keep the English money?
quote:
I offered the
money to my master, but he bade me keep it

text: She visits her son.
quote:
Hearing
that my son was come to this place, I went to see him, and found him
lying flat upon the ground.

text: King Philip's camp. In Connecticut?
quote: THE EIGHTH REMOVE

text: She wants to be taken to Albany
quote:
I desired them that
they would carry me to Albany upon one of those horses, and sell me for
powder

almost as far as
Albany,

text: Recrossing the river?
quote:
we must go five miles
up the river, and then go over it.

text: Stopped at place of an Indian (many indians?)
quote:
Here lived a
sorry Indian,

text: 5 miles up river from Philip's camp
quote: THE NINTH REMOVE

text: She gives her master a knife and is glad that she's made him happy.
quote:
I carried the knife in, and my master asked me to give
it him, and I was not a little glad that I had anything that they would
accept of, and be pleased with.

text: They have corn stores in Narragansett country.
quote:
she had been gone three weeks into the Narragansett
country to fetch corn

text: None of the Indians she passed were at all bad to her.
quote:
yet not one of them offered the least imaginable
miscarriage to me.

text: She gets lost visiting her son a mile away.
quote:
My son being now about a mile from me, I asked liberty to go and
see him; they bade me go, and away I went; but quickly lost myself,
traveling over hills and through swamps, and could not find the way to
him.

text: But her master shows her the way.
quote:
He
showed me the way to my son.

text: This woman is very nice to her.
quote:
I went to the same
squaw, who had a kettle of ground nuts boiling. I asked her to let me
boil my piece of bear in her kettle, which she did, and gave me some
ground nuts to eat with it: and I cannot but think how pleasant it
was to me.

text: 3/4 of a mile further up river
quote: THE TENTH REMOVE

text: She walks back to ninth remove to get food.
quote:
being hungry, I
went again back to the place we were before at, to get something to eat

text: But another Indian makes her go back to her master's camp.
quote:
When I
was there, there came an Indian to look after me, who when he had found
me, kicked me all along.

text: Crossed the river and took to hilly land.
quote:
I took my load at my back, and quickly we came to
wade over the river; and passed over tiresome and wearisome hills.

text: travelling up river and over hills
quote: THE ELEVENTH REMOVE

text: Presumably a good thing. Seems to mean "a thing of no value." Actually means "nut" or similar.
quote: Nux

text: Mistress tries to throw away her bible.
quote:
My mistress,
before we went, was gone to the burial of a papoose, and returning, she
found me sitting and reading in my Bible; she snatched it hastily out of
my hand, and threw it out of doors. I ran out and catched it up, and put
it into my pocket, and never let her see it afterward.

text: They seem to be going back to English territory.
quote: But the thoughts of my going homeward (for so we bent our course)

text: Mistress demands to go back and she has to go with her.
quote:
a sudden my mistress gives
out; she would go no further, but turn back again, and said I must go
back again with her

text: Master continues onwards.
quote:
he would not, but said he would go on, and come
to us again in three days.

text: She wasn't allowed to sleep in the wigwam that night.
quote:
but when we came to lie down they
bade me to go out, and lie somewhere else

text: An old Indian couple took her in for the night.
quote:
last an old Indian bade me to come to him, and his squaw gave
me some ground nuts; she gave me also something to lay under my head,
and a good fire we had

text: 2 miles from the Connecticut river.
quote:
We
were at this place and time about two miles from [the] Connecticut
river.

text: 2 miles from the Connecticut river
quote: THE TWELFTH REMOVE

text: 5 or 6 miles down river (not towards the bay)
quote:
five or six miles down the river into a mighty thicket of
brush; where we abode almost a fortnight.

text: in the brush, further downriver
quote: THE THIRTEENTH REMOVE

text: Random Indian tells her her son's been eaten. She doesn't fall for it.
quote:
He answered me that such a time his master roasted him, and that himself
did eat a piece of him, as big as his two fingers, and that he was very
good meat.

text: The Indians are kind of jerks.
quote:
A squaw moved it down again, at which I
looked up, and she threw a handful of ashes in mine eyes.

text: Hadley
quote: Hadley

text: Attempted defiance
quote:
With that my mistress rises up, and take up a stick big enough to have
killed me, and struck at me with it. But I stepped out, and she struck
the stick into the mat of the wigwam.

text: Her son's Indians attempt to trade with the French, but the Mohawks prevent them from doing so.
quote:
He told me also, that awhile before, his master (together with
other Indians) were going to the French for powder; but by the way the
Mohawks met with them, and killed four of their company, which made the
rest turn back again, for it might have been worse with him, had he
been sold to the French, than it proved to be in his remaining with the
Indians.

text: Englishman laying on the ground in a shirt with an orphaned baby.
quote:
They had turned him out of the wigwam, and with him an
Indian papoose, almost dead (whose parents had been killed), in a bitter
cold day, without fire or clothes.

text: She's no longer allowed out of the wigwam.
quote:
They told me I lied, and taking up a hatchet, they came
to me, and said they would knock me down if I stirred out again, and so
confined me to the wigwam.

text: She gets her son sold to a new master because he was gone too long.
quote:
Which he did, and it seems
tarried a little too long; for his master was angry with him, and beat
him, and then sold him. Then he came running to tell me he had a new
master, and that he had given him some ground nuts already.

text: Last time she sees her son. He seems to be in good hands.
quote:
So his master carried him away, and I never saw him afterward,
till I saw him at Piscataqua in Portsmouth.

text: Her mistress's baby dies, and she gets put out of the wigwam again.
quote:
My mistress's
papoose was sick, and it died that night, and there was one benefit in
it—that there was more room.

text: She didn't feel bad for her mistress losing a child. There's a surprise.
quote:
I confess I could not much condole
with them.

text: headed towards Baytowns
quote:
our course
toward the Baytowns

text: on the move towards Baytowns
quote: THE FOURTEENTH REMOVE

text: Banquaug river again
quote:
We came to Banquang river again that day, near which we abode
a few days.

text: Banquang river
quote: THE FIFTEENTH REMOVE

text: food/ provisions
quote: victuals

text: what does this mean?
quote: samp

text: intense, passionate, violent
quote: vehemency

text: dead
quote: knocked on the head

text: graphic
quote:
split open
his bowels

text: saddest
quote: dolefulest

text: where
quote: whither

my son came
to me
text: she has a son
across the Banquang river
quote: THE SIXTEENTH REMOVAL

text: She has a lot of problems crossing the river.
quote:
I was so weak and feeble, that I reeled
as I went along, and thought there I must end my days at last, after
my bearing and getting through so many difficulties.

text: She's Wachusett-bound, where her master is.
quote:
I must go
to Wachusett to my master

text: Only moved one mile, and stayed there two days.
quote:
Yet it pleased them to go but
one mile that night, and there we stayed two days.

text: Indians in English clothing.
quote:
first sight
of them, for they were dressed in English apparel, with hats, white
neckcloths, and sashes about their waists; and ribbons upon their
shoulders

text: Indian town
quote: At night we came to an Indian town

text: indian town
quote: THE SEVENTEENTH REMOVE

text: dead naked Englishman
quote:
Englishman stripped naked, and lying dead
upon the ground, but knew not who it was.

text: a second indian town
quote: THE EIGHTEENTH REMOVE

text: She comes across one of her nieces.
quote:
In this town there were four English
children, captives; and one of them my own sister's.

text: She stole food from a child?
quote:
Then I took it of the child, and
eat it myself, and savory it was to my taste.

text: Her mistress tells her to stop begging for food. She tells them they can beat her or kill her by starvation.
quote:
Then I went home to my mistress's wigwam; and
they told me I disgraced my master with begging, and if I did so any
more, they would knock me in the head. I told them, they had as good
knock me in head as starve me to death.
THE NINETEENTH REMOVE
text: trying to get to Wachusett, near Sudbury
within sight of Wachusett
quote:
I
saw Wachusett hills

text: King Philip tells her she's going to see her master?
quote:
Going
along, having indeed my life, but little spirit, Philip, who was in the
company, came up and took me by the hand, and said, two weeks more and
you shall be mistress again.

text: Her master lets her bathe and gets her food.
quote:
He asked me, when I washed me? I told
him not this month. Then he fetched me some water himself, and bid me
wash, and gave me the glass to see how I looked; and bid his squaw give
me something to eat.

text: She had been traveling with her master's second wife.
quote:
Another was Wattimore [Weetamoo]
with whom I had lived and served all this while.

text: Second wife wants her back; first wife tells her to come to her for food and shelter at night.
quote:
Weetamoo's maid came to call me home, at which I fell
aweeping. Then the old squaw told me, to encourage me, that if I wanted
victuals, I should come to her, and that I should lie there in her
wigwam.

text: Second wife wants to keep her in her wigwam so she gets paid the ransom, basically.
quote:
I understood that Weetamoo
thought that if she should let me go and serve with the old squaw, she
would be in danger to lose not only my service, but the redemption pay
also.

text: Tom and Peter?
quote: Tom and Peter

text: How would she have sent for her husband?
quote:
So that fearing the worst, I durst not send
to my husband, though there were some thoughts of his coming to redeem
and fetch me, not knowing what might follow.

text: The General Court of the Sagamores sets her ransom.
quote:
Sagamores met to consult about the captives, and called me to them
to inquire how much my husband would give to redeem me.

text: A Christian Indian writes to Boston for her ransom.
quote:
ut they would not
hear of that, but sent that message to Boston, that for twenty pounds I
should be redeemed. It was a Praying Indian that wrote their letter
for them.

text: Lots of Praying Indian stories follow:
quote:
There was another Praying Indian, who told me, that he had
a brother, that would not eat horse

text: Then they go out and attack Sudbury?
quote:
One Englishman they brought along with them: and he
said, it was too true, for they had made sad work at Sudbury, as indeed
it proved.

text: They left happy and rejoicing, came back quietly and as if they'd lost. But she didn't think they'd lost any men.
quote:
When
they went, they acted as if the devil had told them that they should
gain the victory; and now they acted as if the devil had told them they
should have a fall.

text: They did eventually get destroyed (by the english presumably).
quote:
Whither it were so or no, I cannot tell, but so it
proved, for quickly they began to fall, and so held on that summer, till
they came to utter ruin.

text: An Indian that would feed her often told her he'd killed two Englishmen at Sudbury and had their clothing.
quote:
Which I did, and as I
was eating, another Indian said to me, he seems to be your good friend,
but he killed two Englishmen at Sudbury, and there lie their clothes
behind you: I looked behind me, and there I saw bloody clothes, with
bullet-holes in them

text: 3 or 4 miles away from the camp they attacked Sudbury from
quote: THE TWENTIETH REMOVE

We went
about three or four miles, and there they built a great wigwam, big
enough to hold an hundred Indians, which they did in preparation to a
great day of dancing.

text: Her sister tries to see her, but doesn't.
quote:
Then he overtook her, and began to rant as if he had been mad, and made
her go back again in the rain; so that I never saw her till I saw her
in Charlestown.

text: Her daughter was also near, but she didn't get to see her.
quote:
My daughter was also now about a
mile off,

text: They terrorize an Englishman that shows up.
quote:
I told them I thought they had killed the Englishman (for they
had in the meantime informed me that an Englishman was come). They said,
no. They shot over his horse and under and before his horse, and they
pushed him this way and that way, at their pleasure, showing what they
could do.

text: Her husband sent her tobacco?
quote:
Amongst other things which my husband sent me,
there came a pound of tobacco, which I sold for nine shillings in money;
for many of the Indians for want of tobacco, smoked hemlock, and ground
ivy.

text: The Indians stole food and cloth from the Englishman.
quote:
In
the morning Mr. Hoar invited the Sagamores to dinner; but when we went
to get it ready we found that they had stolen the greatest part of the
provision Mr. Hoar had brought, out of his bags, in the night

text: Her master and mistress get dressed up to dance.
quote:
He was dressed in his holland shirt, with great
laces sewed at the tail of it; he had his silver buttons, his white
stockings, his garters were hung round with shillings, and he had
girdles of wampum upon his head and shoulders. She had a kersey coat,
and covered with girdles of wampum from the loins upward. Her arms from
her elbows to her hands were covered with bracelets; there were handfuls
of necklaces about her neck, and several sorts of jewels in her ears.
She had fine red stockings, and white shoes, her hair powdered and face
painted red, that was always before black.

text: Her master says he'll give her back for a pint of alcohol.
quote:
When we were lain down, my master went out of the wigwam, and
by and by sent in an Indian called James the Printer, who told Mr. Hoar,
that my master would let me go home tomorrow, if he would let him have
one pint of liquors.

text: The Englishman gets "his Indians" to find him alcohol.
quote:
Then Mr. Hoar called his own Indians, Tom and
Peter, and bid them go and see whether he would promise it before them
three; and if he would, he should have it; which he did, and he had it.

text: Her master gets drunk off of a pint.
quote:
My master after he had had his drink, quickly came
ranting into the wigwam again, and called for Mr. Hoar, drinking to him,
and saying, he was a good man, and then again he would say, "hang him
rogue."

text: Then the General Court decides she should go home?
quote:
On Tuesday morning they called their general court (as they call it) to
consult and determine, whether I should go home or no. And they all
as one man did seemingly consent to it, that I should go home; except
Philip, who would not come among them.

text: Metacomet shows up and makes her give him things in return for good news.
quote:
Then Philip smelling the business called me to him, and asked me what I
would give him, to tell me some good news, and speak a good word for
me. I told him I could not tell what to give him. I would [give him]
anything I had, and asked him what he would have? He said two coats
and twenty shillings in money, and half a bushel of seed corn, and some
tobacco. I thanked him for his love; but I knew the good news as well
as the crafty fox.

text: There had been army men at her town until they left to get more provisions a week before the attack. (Unsurprisingly, the Indians had been starving too.)
quote:
I say, that then our army should want provision, and be forced to leave
their pursuit and return homeward; and the very next week the enemy came
upon our town, like bears bereft of their whelps, or so many ravenous
wolves, rending us and our lambs to death.

text: The Indians were scornful of the English army.
quote:
Thus did they scoff at us, as if the English would be a quarter of a
year getting ready.

text: The Indians had been running from the fresh English army by crossing an impassable river.
quote: fled before them till they came to Banquang river

text: None of the Indians died of hunger, even though the English strategy was starve them out.
quote:
I did not see
(all the time I was among them) one man, woman, or child, die with
hunger.

text: The Indians ate everything.
quote:
They would eat horse's guts, and ears, and all sorts of wild birds
which they could catch; also bear, venison, beaver, tortoise, frogs,
squirrels, dogs, skunks, rattlesnakes; yea, the very bark of trees

eleven weeks and five
days

text: The Indians attacked Englishpeople a lot.
quote:
one week passed without the fury of the enemy, and some
desolation by fire and sword upon one place or other. They mourned (with
their black faces) for their own losses, yet triumphed and rejoiced in
their inhumane, and many times devilish cruelty to the English.

text: They didn't want her to go home until they did. Then they wanted her to send them things.
quote:
At first they were all against it, except my
husband would come for me, but afterwards they assented to it, and
seemed much to rejoice in it; some asked me to send them some bread,
others some tobacco, others shaking me by the hand, offering me a hood
and scarfe to ride in; not one moving hand or tongue against it.

About
the sun going down, Mr. Hoar, and myself, and the two Indians came
to Lancaster, and a solemn sight it was to me.
text: She finally returns to Lancaster.
Lancaster was destroyed.
quote:
now not one
Christian to be seen, nor one house left standing.

text: Concord
quote: we came to Concord.

text: Meets her brother and brother-in-law.
quote:
There
I met with my brother, and my brother-in-law, who asked me, if I knew
where his wife was?

text: Her brother-in-law had buried his own wife without recognizing her (burnt).
quote:
She being shot down by the house was partly burnt, so that
those who were at Boston at the desolation of the town, and came back
afterward, and buried the dead, did not know her.

text: She goes to Boston and meets her husband.
quote:
Being recruited
with food and raiment we went to Boston that day, where I met with my
dear husband, but the thoughts of our dear children, one being dead, and
the other we could not tell where, abated our comfort each to other.

text: Her ransom was raised by charity.
quote:
The twenty pounds, the price of my redemption,
was raised by some Boston gentlemen, and Mrs. Usher, whose bounty and
religious charity, I would not forget to make mention of.

text: Her sister and a woman she knew were also ransomed/returned.
quote: they brought in my sister, and goodwife Kettle.

And as we were
riding along (God is the wise disposer of all things) between Ipswich
and Rowley we met with Mr. William Hubbard, who told us that our son
Joseph was come in to Major Waldron's, and another with him, which was
my sister's son.
text: She gets news of her son and nephew (who are at Major Waldron's). Between Ipswich and Rowley.
Newbury
quote: Newbury

text: Salisbury
quote: Salisbury

text: They hear her daughters is at Providence.
quote:
his daughter was come in at
Providence.

text: They retrieve their son from Portsmouth for 7 pounds.
quote:
Our son being nearest, we
went to him first, to Portsmouth, where we met with him, and with the
Major also,

text: return to Newbury
quote: Newbury

text: Charlestown
quote: Charlestown

text: Rehoboth and Rhode Island
quote: Rehoboth than Rhode Island

text: They retrieved her daughter at Dorchester.
quote:
But the carts which
carried provision to the English army, being guarded, brought her with
them to Dorchester, where we received her safe.

text: She traveled 3 days with an Indian woman to come to Providence
quote:
Thus she
traveled three days together, not knowing whither she was going;

text: The family moves to Boston
quote:
the South Church in Boston hired an house for us. Then we removed from
Mr. Shepard's, those cordial friends, and went to Boston, where we
continued about three-quarters of a year.

quote:
split open
his bowels

text: "pagan". Descriptions of Indians have a religious backdrop.
quote: heathen

text: explicit reference to blood. Third or so mention in this passage
quote:
blood
running down to our heels
I must turn my back upon the town

repeated mention of "knocking in the head". Why?
quote: knock your child in the head

quote: and that Scripture came to my hand

text: oddly matter-of-factly. The narrator has grown numb to death
quote:
there was one benefit in
it—that there was more room

text: doubting herself
quote:
I began to think that all my
hopes of restoration would come to nothing

text: what does this mean
quote:
I would tell the world what a blessing the Lord gave
to such mean food

text: justifying not being satisfied after her meal
quote:
Thou shalt eat and not
be satisfied

When thou
passest through the waters, I will be with thee; and through the rivers,

text: false hope
quote:
My heart
skipped within me, thinking they had been Englishmen

text: hope
quote:
Yes, and quickly you shall come to your master again; who had been gone
from us three weeks

text: more hope
quote:
being by it raised in
my hopes, that in God's due time there would be an end of this sorrowful
hour

text: describing horrible Indian actions
quote:
so wicked and cruel,
as to wear a string about his neck,

text: hope diminishing
quote:
the
governor would be so angry for his loss at Sudbury, that he would send
no more about the captives

text: wouldn't let her go see her daughter, who was only a mile away
quote:
They made use of their tyrannical power whilst they
had it; but through the Lord's wonderful mercy, their time was now but
short

God many times leaving us most in the dark, when
deliverance is nearest
God had an over-ruling hand in all those things

text: food they ate
quote:
The chief and commonest food was ground nuts. They eat also nuts and
acorns, artichokes, lilly roots, ground beans, and several other weeds
and roots, that I know not.

text: total time she was taken
quote:
eleven weeks and five
days

text: Indians would boast about their accomplishments
quote:
boast
how many towns they had destroyed,

text: family back together
quote: Our family being now gathered together

text: appreciating what she has now
quote:
It is then hard work to persuade myself, that ever I should be satisfied
with bread again. But now we are fed with the finest of the wheat

text: friends came to help them
quote:
house
furnished with love.

text: something that causes pain or suffering
quote: affliction

text: interesting comment
quote:
That they are the vanity of vanities, and vexation of spirit, that they
are but a shadow, a blast, a bubble, and things of no continuance.

text: more appreciation
quote:
I have learned to
look beyond present and smaller troubles, and to be quieted under them

text: 338 years ago today
quote: tenth of February 1675

text: 'Removal' instead of 'Remove'. Typo?
quote: REMOVAL

text: A young North American Indian child
quote: papoose

text: A married male Native American
quote: sannup

text: they want her alive?
quote:
I told them the skin was off my back, but I had no other
comforting answer from them than this: that it would be no matter if my
head were off too.

text: abuse
quote:
A squaw moved it down again, at which I
looked up, and she threw a handful of ashes in mine eyes.

text: feelings of hopelessness and desperation
quote:
About this time I began to think that all my
hopes of restoration would come to nothing. I thought of the English
army, and hoped for their coming, and being taken by them, but that
failed. I hoped to be carried to Albany, as the Indians had discoursed
before, but that failed also.

text: conflict. example of Mary Rowlandson retaliating against her captors.
quote:
I told her I would not. Then my mistress bade me give it,
but still I said no. The maid told me if I would not give her a piece,
she would tear a piece off it. I told her I would tear her coat then.
With that my mistress rises up, and take up a stick big enough to have
killed me, and struck at me with it.

text: justified stealing meat from a child
quote:
Thus the Lord made that pleasant refreshing, which another time would
have been an abomination.

text: she would rather die quickly than slowly
quote:
I told them, they had as good
knock me in head as starve me to death.

text: An American Indian wife or woman
quote: squaw

text: food or provisions
quote: victuals

text: "Praying Indians" were punished
quote: Praying Indian

text: time elapsed
quote: nine or ten weeks

text: demonstration of resiliency in nature
quote:
that I did not see
(all the time I was among them) one man, woman, or child, die with
hunger

text: her tastes have changed
quote:
It is then hard work to persuade myself, that ever I should be satisfied
with bread again.

text: she observes how quickly life can change without warning
quote:
I have seen the extreme vanity of this world: One hour I have been in
health, and wealthy, wanting nothing. But the next hour in sickness and
wounds, and death, having nothing but sorrow and affliction.

text: she wished for affliction when she recognized that she was living in great prosperity
quote:
When I lived in prosperity, having the comforts of the world about
me, my relations by me, my heart cheerful, and taking little care for
anything, and yet seeing many, whom I preferred before myself, under
many trials and afflictions, in sickness, weakness, poverty, losses,
crosses, and cares of the world, I should be sometimes jealous least I
should have my portion in this life, and that Scripture would come to my
mind

text: King Philips War (1675-78)
quote:
tenth of February 1675, came the Indians with great numbers upon
Lancaster

text: she would not be killed, she would be held captive
quote:
But to return: the Indians laid hold of us, pulling me one
way, and the children another, and said, "Come go along with us"; I told
them they would kill me: they answered, if I were willing to go along
with them, they would not hurt me.

text: change of perspective. she had thought about being captured by Native Americans before?
quote:
I had often before this said that if the Indians should come, I should
choose rather to be killed by them than taken alive, but when it came
to the trial my mind changed

text: interesting biblical reference
quote:
See now that I, even I am he, and there is no
god with me, I kill and I make alive, I wound and I heal, neither is
there any can deliver out of my hand.

text: what is the dreadful hour?
quote: Now is the dreadful hour come

text: very puritan, as we discussed on Monday
quote:
I
hope she is reaping the fruit of her good labors, being faithful to the
service of God in her place

text: What?
quote:
More than twenty
years after, I have heard her tell how sweet and comfortable that place
was to her.

text: Are they asking if she intends to still love an English man? In other words, the only way for her to sleep in a tipi is to sleep with an Indian
quote:
What,
will you love English men still

text: she thinks that this suffering is designed for her and her alone, she appreciates the solitude and sees it as a chance to become closer to her religion since it is a significant affliction
quote:
yet
so it must be, that I must sit all this cold winter night upon the cold
snowy ground, with my sick child in my arms, looking that every hour
would be the last of its life; and having no Christian friend near me,
either to comfort or help me

text: is there any comfort gained from having her child "quickly" knocked in the head? Is this their attempts to make things a little (very little) easier/
quote:
"your master
will knock your child in the head," and then a second, and then a third,
"your master will quickly knock your child in the head."

text: yes
quote: This was the comfort I had from them

I have thought since of the wonderful goodness of
God to me in preserving me in the use of my reason and senses in that
distressed time, that I did not use wicked and violent means to end my
own miserable life
